text: if you go into the center of Taliban
which is on the other side of the bay
from here life looks very much like it's
getting back to normal there are
bustling streets full of cars and people
the shops are open they're stuffed full
of goods but down here on the coast
which was hit by far the hardest by the
typhoon things are very different people
are still living in tents you can see
here if they're lucky they've been able
to construct a Shack and cover it with a
tarpaulin there is still an enormous aid
operation going on here with dozens of
international and local NGOs helping
people out I mean some of it is very
well coordinated some of it far less but
it is nevertheless definitely making a
huge difference no one here is going
hungry
and no one was it is without some form
of shelter but the question now six
months on is how are these people going
to restart their lives how are they
going to find work where are they going
to get money from and it really is
really striking how huge the gap is
between here in a developing world
country hit by a disaster and the
developed world when you hear about a
storm hitting the United States or an
earthquake here in Japan for example
immediately we hear about the massive
insurance payouts in the tens of
billions of US dollars but people here
no one had insurance so they've lost
their homes they've lost their cars
their businesses their fishing boats and
now they have nothing they have no
collateral they have no way to get a
bank loan the question then is how do
you start your life over again
